text.p: The following are top headlines from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- General Jean Boyle leaves defence post: Embattled general resigns after lukewarm support from new minister.
- Lieutenant-General Maurice Baril favoured to lead Forces: Army head cited as likely pick.
- Casinos called open door to mob: Secret report says Ontario needs tighter rein on bingo, charity gambling.
- Ottawa wins key ruling in Airbus case: Lawyers can go to Switzerland to question Swiss official about Royal Canadian Mounted Police's letter.
- Gamble on West Bank peace proves risky: A Canadian who moved his family to Ramallah from the safety of Montreal finds himself setting up first-aid classes.
- Finance Minister Paul Martin to cut deficit target: Expected to set new goal at one percent of gross domestic product in 1998-99 and to reveal lower figure for 1995-96.
- Report urges overhaul of Canada Post: Ottawa rejects bulk of 31 proposals.
- Strike threatens General Motors car launches: Domino effect expected in U.S. after Windsor plants close.
- Is pattern bargaining breaking down? Employers are refusing to follow patterns, arguing that one size doesn't fit all anymore. But unions are reluctant to try that on.
- Stick to letters, Canada Post told: Report says post office should get out of the courier business and stop delivering flyers. Ottawa agrees on flyers but says Purolator Courier is not for sale.
- Canadian Auto Workers strike to hit General Motors' hot-selling models.
